documents.document: A very helpful thread outlining how current #covid19 vaccines are effective against circulating variants in real-world scenarios. We still need to keep a close watch on emerging variants, but to date, mass vaccination seems to do the job. Vaccines are winning. https://t.co/lh10qUBLCc

@CityMelanie @breakfasttv Great to chat with you. I didnt know this (may the fourth) was a thing. Turns out its a thing. Also nice to discuss AZ and JJ vaccines today. I hope we cleared up a few issues.
@meg_michael_ Excellent point.

Honest conversations about the Risks, Benefits, Alternatives Context enable people to make informed decisions... ...and after this thought exercise, many have suggested to take (and/or receive) the 1st available #COVID19 vaccine (which is very reasonable).

AZ/J+J vaccines - helpful to explain: 1. Benefits: Protection from dangerous infection, spillover benefit to family, close contacts 2. Risk: Incidence of clotting events 3. Alternatives: Waiting for mRNA vaccines 4. Context: Large 3rd wave in , younger ages in hospital/ICU https://t.co/kEoNAtvfHv

@EdTubb I agree. They have been consistent. Its also important to contextualize risk. These are potentially life-saving vaccines, but we have to be transparent about the risk enable informed decision making. Weve never had this much COVID-19, and these vaccines can ( do) save lives.

2/ Proof of vaccination to cross an international border is a contentious issue for some, but 1. People can choose to be vaccinated (or not) 2. People travel 3. Sovereign countries determine border policy as they see fit ... circles on that Venn diagram may not always overlap.

1/ More details from the European Union regarding #COVID19 vaccinations travel: "...anyone who has received the last dose of an EU-approved vaccine at least two weeks beforehand will be permitted to travel." Details https://t.co/Z6YJhE2Ey4

The World Health Organization just updated #COVID19 transmission info, discussing that the infection is mainly transmitted in close proximity (1m), but longer-range transmission is possible in poorly ventilated/crowded spaces. Glad to see this. Source: https://t.co/TfNEiNOSDE https://t.co/MxCXQVwXsk
@JonHerriot Yes
1. Provincial website to book an appointment: https://t.co/So50giA2fj 2. Provincial phone number to book an appointment: 1-833-943-3900

Starting tomorrow (May 3), EVERYONE 18 years older living in 114 Ontario postal codes highly-impacted by #COVID19 will be eligible to book a vaccine appointment on the provincial/public health websites. Source: https://t.co/ON2oioeR04 114 "hot-spot" postal codes: https://t.co/ef8hAAtWEl

@rubiconcapital_ That's basically it. I don't see how, as Canadians, we would have influence over another country's health policy. Do you? If we choose to not be vaccinated, we will be limited. We may as well have the infrastructure to properly document vaccination for those who choose it.

@rubiconcapital_ Regardless, people can choose to believe that COVID is serious or not/get vaccinated or not. But a growing list of countries recognize that COVID is a PH threat are requiring proof of vaccination. Those who chose to not be vaccinated will have limited travel options. Simple.
@rubiconcapital_ Uuuuhhhh....have you seen whats happening in healthcare systems where the virus transmits unchecked? Tons of examples globally. Im in ON. Its bad. Its a PH threat by any measure.

@rubiconcapital_ @janephilpott Both c19 and yf are significant public health threats - both can cause large outbreaks, cause significant illness in some of those infected, and overwhelm healthcare system capacity. Both are vaccine preventable.

@rubiconcapital_ @janephilpott Hi Kelly, the key here is that there is precedent for demonstrating vaccination to a communicable disease (that poses a public health threat) for the purpose of crossing an international border. Seen with smallpox, meningococcus, yellow fever, COVID etc.
@DFisman @AshTuite Thanks for sharing. Good news - preliminary, but more evidence suggesting current vaccines will have some efficacy.
@zchagla @TorontoIDDoc @janephilpott Digitize it on the passport or travel document.
@janephilpott Agree 100%
@Nikikgray @alanmcn1 One deep fried caterpillar cake, please.

Addendum: Just FYI, there are countries that require Yellow Fever vaccination, regardless (above). There are *many* other countries that require proof of vaccination for those travelling from a region where Yellow Fever is endemic. https://t.co/dM1g00Dw6H https://t.co/noVl7r6Whc

@NoahIvers @VaxHuntersCan I tried it this AM and it worked really well. This is all thanks to @ZainManji and @VaxHuntersCan - dedicated volunteers making useful work-arounds for our convoluted sign-up system. @KamilKaramali has a great write up of how this came to be here: https://t.co/J3Ujdq1NXx

5/ So regardless of our opinions on the matter, it appears that proof of #COVID19 vaccination will be required for international travel. May as well be ahead of the curve quickly find ways to electronically/securely document vaccination status, that meets global standards.

4/ There is precedent for this. Many countries require proof of Yellow Fever vaccination to enter. If you show up without proper documentation you either: 1. get turned around at the border, or 2. get vaccinated at the border (if available). Source: https://t.co/lRfZilCn53 https://t.co/3WB8RFYtsq
3/ #COVID19 vaccine certification for travel will likely be a global norm: https://t.co/37dLzxJoAx

2/ There are a growing number of countries requiring proof of #COVID19 vaccination for travel...18 are currently listed here. Also the EU just announced they would be open to vaccinated travellers from the USA this summer. https://t.co/9VOeqMpCwe

1. "Health Minister Patty Hajdu says her government embraces the concept of 'vaccine passports' will come up with a form of certification to allow vaccinated Canadians to travel internationally." Smart move good to be proactive. https://t.co/ulfbPb8bSx by @peterzimonjic

RT @CBCAlerts: 1st shipment of Johnson Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine now in Canada. 304,800 doses of the vaccine arrived at Toronto's Pearso

8. With time, vaccines will help us return to normalcy. Take home points: -Vaccines work really really well -2 doses better than 1, but 1 still really good -Maintain precautions after 1 dose, you are not invincible We'll get through this.

7. Also, while these vaccines are really really good, they are not perfect. People can still get sick even after 2 doses. It's pretty uncommon, but it can happen. The CDC discusses it here: https://t.co/7bK2rldjwW https://t.co/7sjQuxixaV

6. So what do we do? The same thing we've been doing all along...mask indoors, avoid close, confined, crowded settings. Ventilate rooms. Spend time outdoors. You know...the usual. Also, we'll probably get 2nd doses before 4 month due to supply. (Probably).
5/ So can you get #COVID19 even 2 weeks after your 1st dose? Of course - but your risk is much lower. Can you get really sick? Sure - but your risk is also much lower.

4/ But going back to the 1st point, while 1 dose provides pretty decent protection from #COVID19, 2 doses are ideal. Stretching out the interval between dose 1 2 i(in Canada) provides protection to more people over a shorter period of time. This will end our pandemic faster.

3/ Here is some of the data backing up NACI's statement above, but from a clinical trial. This graph below is with Pfizer...look at how people start to gain protection ~12-14 days after their 1st dose (red line). Pretty impressive. Link: https://t.co/SONs86le1N https://t.co/n5OEyXAuK0

2/ NACI outlines protection after 1 dose of a vaccine in their recent document: "Most importantly, these studies show one dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech AstraZeneca vaccines are approximately 80% effective against hospitalization..." Details: https://t.co/jY5TjswFHB https://t.co/js0g7qeGum

1/ A few points to clarify a few points... These vaccines are really really good, but not perfect. One dose of a vaccine provides excellent protection against #COVID19 infection, but of course 2 doses provide more protection. https://t.co/GkV4kvj0bM

@DadEducator "In this prospective observational study, we examined the proportion and probability of self-reported systemic and local side-effects within 8 days of vaccination in individuals using the COVID Symptom Study app..."

Best data to date on side-effects following Pfizer (BNT162b2) AstraZeneca (ChAdOx1 nCoV-19) #COVID19 vaccines. Systemic side-effects were reported in: *13.5% after 1st dose Pfizer *22% after 2nd dose Pfizer *37.7% after 1st dose AZ Link: https://t.co/gvulHDQ3Fm Details https://t.co/i2oVb5qUNL
